column1: A palindromic place is a city or town whose name can be spelled either from left to right or right to left identically. An example of this would be Navan in Ireland. Some of the entries on this list are only palindromic if the next administrative division they are a part of is also included in the name
Because the names here come from a variety of languages

Diacritics are marks placed on or near letters to give them a modified pronunciation. Some languages treat such as completely different letters; others treat them as variants of the base letter. The latter group is summarized here. Only place names where the language of the country is in the latter group are included here when diacritics make for an apparent non-palindrome.

column3: Kazakh) have two or more vowels that resemble the I. They are differentiated by the number of dots above the letter: zero
column5: or two. These dots appear on both lower and upper case letters. For places in Turkey
column8: only those vowels that have the same number of dots will be considered equal here.

column1: The ʻokina is a consonant found in several Polynesian languages. It's pronounced as a glottal stop and is often represented by an apostrophe. Because English wordplay generally ignores apostrophes
column2: it's common to ignore ʻokinas in determining the palindrommicity of Polynesian names. However
column3: this list will not follow that rule. Unbalanced ʻokinas will not be found in this list.
